description: From Middle English plaisaunce, plesaunce, from Old French plaisance.

entries.meaning: A pleasure ground laid out with shady walks, trees and shrubs, statuary, and ornamental water; a secluded part of a garden. [from 16th c.]
examples: the pleasances of old Elizabethan houses

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Willingness to please, or the action of pleasing; courtesy. [14th–17th c.]
(obsolete) The feeling of being pleased; pleasure, delight. [14th–19th c.]
